According to the 3rd Law of motion, if a centripetal force exists then a centrifugal force must always exist. I get that the net force acting ON object A in uniform circular motion must be towards the center (centripetal); therefore, the acceleration is centripetal. However, whatever object is interacting ON object A must also be experiencing the same interaction BY object A. I think physicist calling a force (like friction or normal) acting outward on an object as "fictitious" is misleading and counteracts our struggles in teaching the 3rd Law.   For example, the key spinning in the video is being pulled inward by the string. The net force on the key is inward as a result of the tension. According to 3rd Law, the key is pulling the string outward - centrifugal in direction. At 8:33, the narrator almost mentions this by briefly commenting that "you'll feel the key pulling harder on your fingers." - again, the tension is centrifugal in direction. BTW, to derive v^2/r does not take calculus, kids with a bit of trig can be lead through dv/dt on a circle.

'Centrifugal force' actually does exist. It is called fictitious because the rotating reference frame is not inertial. However the tendency of objects in a rotating reference frame to accelerate radially outwards , which is what we are calling 'centrifugal force' is very real. It isn't technically a 'force', because 'radially outwards' is not a valid vector direction in a rotating reference frame, but the phenomenon still exists, and from the rotating reference frame, it behaves exactly as a force does.

Well, Newton's 3rd Law occurs between 2 objects. Yes. The wall pushes against you while you push against the wall - the 3rd Law. But what's pushing YOU against the wall? Nothing, really. You would move in a straight line - if not for the wall pushing you toward the centre of the ride. This is why that outward force is deemed fictitious.

When you are spinning, the ride itself (the seat you're sitting on) is connected to the center, and it experiences tension force as centripetal force. You, however, aren't directly connected to the center of the ride so there is no tension force pulling you inwards. Your inertia makes you move in a straight line tangent to the circle. However, the wall of the ride is in the way, and exerts an equal and opposite force on your body, keeping you from going in a straight line, and that normal force is centripetal force for you.  So basically what you feel isn't normal force, it's your inertia. Normal force is what's keeping you on the circular path.

Sthaman, you may find the following of interest: centripetal force and centrifugal force, action-reaction force pair associated with circular motion. According to Newton's first law of motion, a moving body travels along a straight path with constant speed (i.e., has constant velocity) unless it is acted on by an outside force. For circular motion to occur there must be a constant force acting on a body, pushing it toward the center of the circular path. This force is the centripetal ("center-seeking") force. For a planet orbiting the sun, the force is gravitational; for an object twirled on a string, the force is mechanical; for an electron orbiting an atom, it is electrical. The magnitude F of the centripetal force is equal to the mass m of the body times its velocity squared v  2 divided by the radius r of its path: F = mv 2/ r. According to Newton's third law of motion, for every action there is an equal and opposite reaction. The centripetal force, the action, is balanced by a reaction force, the centrifugal ("center-fleeing") force. The two forces are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction. The centrifugal force does not act on the body in motion; the only force acting on the body in motion is the centripetal force. The centrifugal force acts on the source of the centripetal force to displace it radially from the center of the path. Thus, in twirling a mass on a string, the centripetal force transmitted by the string pulls in on the mass to keep it in its circular path, while the centrifugal force transmitted by the string pulls outward on its point of attachment at the center of the path. The centrifugal force is often mistakenly thought to cause a body to fly out of its circular path when it is released; rather, it is the removal of the centripetal force that allows the body to travel in a straight line as required by Newton's first law. If there were in fact a force acting to force the body out of its circular path, its path when released would not be the straight tangential course that is always observed.

Friction only counts when the two surfaces are trying to move at different relative velocities (e.g. the road and a car). When the ride is accelerating you may experience some drag from the surface against your back because it is only this surface and the straps connecting you to the driving force (the motor). When it is at its max speed (no longer accelerating), you are also moving at the same speed so you can be considered at part of its total mass and the only friction is reacting against drag from the air.  You're almost right that there is a force keeping you from going outwards (but it's not outwards, it's tangentially). It's a reaction force from the solid object behind you. At any one moment you are traveling tangentially to the curve of the circle and in the next moment you collide with the wall which has rotated to intercept you (this wall is always facing the centre of the ride, so it nudges you towards the centre). But because of your tangential motion, the nudge simply puts you on another tangential course. This happens constantly, in a smooth, lossless process... rather than you bouncing around. It's just easier to imagine this way.

Imagine another arrow further ahead on the circle's edge, representing the same speed but in a direction tangential to the new point. All right, time for your friendly neighborhood drunken dropout to go over the "complicated" bit she glossed over.  Consider the velocity at two very close points on the circle.  Because the motion is uniform, they have the same magnitude, they're just in different directions.  What we want is the difference between them, which you get by reversing the direction of one and putting it at the end of the other.  So you have an isosceles triangle, where the difference is the base.  Funny, though - don't the radii form an isosceles triangle?  In fact, they're similar, since both are rotated ninety degrees from the radii.  Since they're similar, then the ratio between the difference in the velocities and the chord between the radii is the same as the ratio between the velocities and the radii.  Now, since we're looking for the time derivative, we're looking for the ratio between that difference and the amount of time that's passed.  Since the velocity is constant, the amount of time that's passed is proportional to the distance along the arc between the two radii.  So to sum up, the ratio we're looking for is: the ratio of the velocity to the radius, multiplied by the ratio of the chord to the arc, multiplied by the ratio of the arc to the time.  For the ratio of the chord to the arc, keep in mind that we're talking about the limit - consider a triangle formed by the chord and two tangents at either end of the chord, meeting in the middle.  As the length of the chord shrinks, the ratio of the chord to the tangents approaches 1.  So since we're talking about the limit, we'll say that the ratio of the chord to the arc is 1.  So now we've got the ratio of the velocity to the radius by the ratio of the arc to the time elapsed, which the ratio of the velocity to the radius by the ratio of the circumference to the period.  The ratio of the circumference to the period is in fact the velocity, so you get v^2/r.

In a non inertial reference frame, there is a rate of change of momentum directed away from the center of rotation.  A force is defined as a rate of change of momentum.  Centrifugal force ENTIRELY fits the definition of a force, and hence is one. There is absolutely nothing at all about the definition of a force that centrifugal force does not fit, every single physicist knows this and every single physicist uses the concept of centrifugal force. There is absolutely nothing, at all, about centrifugal force that does not fit the definition of a force. There is more to the world than inertial reference frames.  Classically we have momentum of an object is mass * velocity of the object. ( p = mv ), this is a fairly useful quantity as it's conserved unless you apply a force to it. A force is simply the amount you change momentum by over a certain time period, we say force is defined as: F = dp/dt. Considering an object with a constant mass, there's no change in mass over time so we can just rewrite the equation F = m(dv/dt).  Now velocity is just how the position of an object changes over time, so we rewrite v = dr/dt, giving us F = m (d^2/dt^2)r.  Now in a circular rotating system, the position x of an object that is constant in a non-rotating frame, is clearly not constant, it changes over time, in a direction that is perpendicular to both the 'upwards' direction and the direction out of the disc, which we denote Ω x r, so dr/dt = dr'/dt + Ω x r , where dr'/dt is the speed we see it moving in from a frame that isn't rotating.   F = m d/dt ( dr'/dt + Ω x r ) F = m [ (d^2/dt^2)r' + (d/dt)(Ω x r)]  F = m [ (d^2/dt^2)r' + Ω x (dr'/dt)  + (dΩ/dt) x r + ΩxΩ + Ωx(dr'/dt+Ωxr) F = m[ (d^2/dt^2)r' + Ω x (dr'/dt)+ (dΩ/dt) x r + Ω x (dr'/dt) +Ω x (Ω x r)  ] F = m[ (d^2/dt^2)r' + 2Ω x (dr'/dt)+ (dΩ/dt) x r +Ω x (Ω x r)  ]   Ergo, m [Ω x (Ω x r)] which is directed radially outwards, entirely fits the definition of a force and exists in a rotating frame.

+Emmanuel Adeloye It's important to understand that that equation is for speed, not velocity.  Uniform circular motion is defined as circular motion with a constant speed.  So, any derivative of that equation will be 0.  The acceleration here is related to the fact that the direction of motion is changing, rather than that the speed is changing.  So, the derivative of the velocity will not be 0, even though that of the speed is.  And, the relevant derivative here is with respect to time.

Yes, and?

The force is really towards the centre (it is always in the direction of the string, because the string can only pull and not exert any force in some other direction). The difference is that the object does not stand still as you start to apply this force. It is moving from the beginning. it is just like an object in orbit around the earth, or earth around the sun; the force is pulling it towards the centre but its tangential velocity keeps it from actually getting closer. The initial velocity is the difference; it must have come from somewhere, but that is not the topic of this video.

When you apply a force at a right angle to an object's motion, it doesn't immediately change directions to follow the force. It has velocity to begin with, and you can only get rid of the motion in that direction by cancelling it with a force in the opposite direction.

+connorp3030  Well... not really ( :D) Look at it this way: If you look at the system from the outside, you see an object moving on a circular path. As the velocity can only point into a straight direction there needs to be a force accelerating it inwards all the time to keep it onto the path. This is the centripetal force (Mass of the body x centripetal acceleration).  Now if you are the object you feel the (force of) inertia acting upon you, which always points exactly 180degrees in the other direction of the sum of accelerating forces acting upon you.  So as you can see it depends on what you're looking at.  Maybe it becomes a bit more clear this way, why people say the centrifugal force isn't real (there's another word for it, she's mentioning it in the video, but i'm no native speaker,can't remember it :D): The centrifugal force you feel, if you're inside the system wouldn't be there if there was no centripetal force.
